tutorial.title: Creating Grid Columns
tutorial.descriptionContent: Learn how to create grid columns

lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent: Let's learn how to set the size and number of grid columns. Press the buttons to see how CSS Grid lets us control the number of columns.

lessons.title: Pixel Units
lessons.interactiveContent:
To define grid columns that have a fixed size, we use pixels. Code 100px, 50px and 100px to make columns of different widths.

Make sure to pick 100px, followed by 50px, and finally 100px.

lessons.title: Additional Items
lessons.interactiveContent:
Grid items are displayed based on the number of columns. If there are more items than columns, extra items will be pushed to the next row.

Make sure to pick <div class="grid-item">, followed by 4, and finally </div>.

lessons.title: Auto
lessons.interactiveContent:
Let's take a look at values that adapt to the screen size. Setting a column to auto will make grid items take up as much space as they can.

Make sure to pick auto.

lessons.title: Fractional Units
lessons.interactiveContent:
Grid has a special measurement unit called fr, short for fractional unit. fr distributes the container's available space in fractions.

Make sure to type fr.

lessons.title: Fractional Units II
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we combine fr with other units like px, the space left after adding the px item is what gets distributed in fractions. Code 50px 1fr 1fr.

Make sure to pick 50px, followed by 1fr, and finally 1fr.

lessons.title: Repeat Function
lessons.interactiveContent:
Grid has a shortcut for defining columns quickly, and that's the repeat() function. For example, repeat(3, 1fr) means 3 columns of 1fr each.

Make sure to pick repeat followed by ( and then 3, ,, 1fr, ).

lessons.title: Question: Pixel Units
lessons.interactiveContent:
What units should we use to define a fixed grid column?

PixelsPercentages

Make sure to pick Pixels.

lessons.title: Question: Additional Items
lessons.interactiveContent:
What happens when we have three grid items but only define two columns with grid-template-columns.

The third item is sent to the next rowThe third item stays on the first row if there's enough space

The third item is sent to the next row.

lessons.title: Question: Percentage Values
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which grid column is the largest in size when we set the grid-template-columns to 30% 30% 40%?

The third columnThe second column

The third column.

lessons.title: Question: Fractional Units
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's true about the first and second columns when we set grid-template-columns to 1fr 2fr?

The second column is twice the size the first columnThe first column is twice the size the second column

The second column is twice the size the first column.

lessons.title: Question: Fractional Units II
lessons.interactiveContent:
What happens when we create columns using the following code?

The remaining space on the right is evenly distributed across the last two columnsThe remaining space on the right is evenly distributed across the first two columns

The remaining space on the right is evenly distributed across the last two columns.

lessons.title: Example: Pixel Units
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create three equal grid columns using pixel values.

Make sure to pick grid-template-columns followed by 100px and then 100px, 100px.

lessons.title: Example: Additional Items
lessons.interactiveContent:
Add a fourth grid item.

Make sure to pick < followed by div and then class="item", >, 4, </, div, >.

lessons.title: Example: Percentage Values
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a two-column grid by coding 50% 50%.

Make sure to type 50% 50%.

lessons.title: Example: Fractional Units
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a grid so that the first column is half the width of the other columns.

Make sure to pick 1fr, followed by 2fr, and finally 2fr.

lessons.title: Example: Fractional Units II
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code 40px 1fr 1fr to distribute the remaining space to the second and third columns.

Make sure to type 40px 1fr 1fr.

lessons.title: Example: Fractional Units III
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code 40px 1fr 3fr to distribute the remaining space to the second and third columns in different proportions.

Make sure to pick 40px, followed by 1fr, and finally 3fr.

lessons.title: Example: Repeat Function
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use the repeat() function to create two columns that are 2fr wide each.

Make sure to pick repeat followed by ( and then 2, ,, 2fr, ).
